Python on the VDI: Getting Started (Part I)¶

In this notebook:¶

  1. Load the required (and optional) Python modules
  2. Using Python and iPython

Select and load Python module

To see the available Python versions from within the VDI, use the “module avail” command:

$ module avail python

NOTE: The modules with "-matplotlib" are for the Matplotlib plotting library. These modules need to be loaded after the base Python module.

Next, use the “module load” command to add the selected version to your path:

$ module load python3
NOTE: It will load the default version of python3 on VDI. It is subject to change in the future.

Python2 is no longer supported (see details here), so it is strongly recommended to use python3 from now on. It is worth noting that some old examples using python2 are not compatible with python3.

Additional Python modules

There are also several prebuilt Python-specific modules available on the VDI:

  • iPython
  • NumPy
  • SciPy
  • Matplotlib
  • NetCDF4
  • H5py
  • Cython
  • XArray
  • Pandas

These can be viewed by using “module avail” (in general, most will be found under /apps/Modules/cloud/all).

To load the popular scientific computing package NumPy, for example, you would again use the "module load" command followed by the module name:

$ module load numpy/1.10.4-py3.5

To remove the uncessary module, you can use module unload command.

$ module unload <module name>

Using Python

You can run Python several different ways:

    1. Python interpreter
    1. Python script
    1. iPython

Python interpreter

To launch the Python interpreter, type the following from the command line:

$ python

Try:

>>> print("hello world")

>>> 2 + 3

To exit:

>>> exit()

Simple Python script

Using a text editing tool of your choice, create a new file with the extension ".py".

  • On the VDI, there are several text editors available under the Applications –> Accessories menu.

  • Or alternatively, you can create the file directly from command line using nano or vi, etc.

    $ nano helloworld.py

Add some simple lines of Python code to the file and close:

print("Hello world!")
print("This is my first Python script.")

From command line, run the script:

$ python helloworld.py

iPython

To launch iPython on the VDI (without having to build locally), the iPython module must first be loaded:

$ module load ipython/4.2.0-py3.5

Next, type:

$ ipython

To exit:

$ exit()
